content: The email provider is Google Workspace. I contacted them and they say that the service does support that. Here's the deal. Up until now, when I wanted to send an email from an address of a different user than myself I would go to the account settings and change. For example: user1@mydomain.com to user2@mydomain.com. I only change the part before the @ sign, everything else stays the same so authentication has no problem. But that process is cumbersome because after I send the email I have to go back to account settings and change it back. I was hoping that this function "Customize From Address..." would save me the steps and just send the email out the same way. But, upon checking what the receivers get they appear to get the email coming from my original address, user1@mydomain.com instead of user2@mydomain.com which I used as the temporary From address.
creator: apeleg

content:
What you are suggesting is exactly what the feature was created for. But as you are already aware, google do not support the use of "unregistered" from addresses from "your" account.

My free account, so I assume you paid one, can send mail with a different from if the email address is set up and verified in your account setting on google. Try this link https://mail.google.com/mail/u/0/#settings/accounts under the heading "Send mail as"
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Having to authenticate every address I want to use as "FROM" first on my (paid) Google account kind of defeats the purpose of doing this "on-the-fly."

This Thunderbird feature does not work exactly the same way as simply changing the Email Address in the account setting because emails do go out with the modified address after changing the settings and they do not go out using the "Customize From Address..."

This would have been a perfect solution for me. I have my paid Google account (I have my own domain hosted on Google) setup with a catch all email address. When I communicate with companies I don't trust to not send me spam I use a customized address for them like "macys@mydomain.com" and regardless what I use before @mydomain.com it arrives at my regular email address. Sometimes I'd like to reply to those incoming email from the customized address I have for them but if I have to first go to Gmail to authenticate it it is even more cumbersome than changing the address in the Thunderbird settings. This method of using customized emails let me know right away who's the source of spam to my account, who sold my address, etc.
creator: apeleg

content: First, the email id associated with the SMTP server is the one that sets when the sent message is filed. Generally, if a person has two email ids, they will use two SMTP server setups (even if for the same server) to ensure that each account's messages remain separate. I suggest you revisit why you have just one. Second, some email providers (such as Gmail) provide a system-generated password. Knowing which email provider you use may cause more information to be provided for your situation.
creator: davidsk

content:
The provider is only necessary if you use tasks and because you have your calendar setup to use the provider, of course it disables it when the provider is not present. But the native implementation of caldav has been available for use with Google calendar for about 10 years now. But it does not do tasks, hence my asking about that specifically.

Want to try it out. Select New from the menu and select calendar and on the network. enter your gmail username (no URL despite what you might read elsewhere) and follow the prompts to what is basically the same sort of dialog the provider offers, listing your calendars to be selected for inclusion in Thunderbird.

content: On old computer, look for this file: profiles.ini. It will be at what was c:\users\<yourID>\appdata\roaming\thunderbird. View it with any simple text editor and it will have a PATH statement that points to the profile folder. Copy that folder to a USB or otherwise make available. On new PC, start thunderbird, ignore the prompt for new email id, click 'home' tab, select the 'import' button and select the option to import profile from another machine. If your saved profile is intact, all should go smoothly.
creator: davidsk

content: 'Bulk' is the name applied by services like AOL/Yahoo to the folder for spam or junk mail, so messages are placed there by the filter rules applied at the mail provider's end. Unblock or whitelist senders by using the controls available on the webmail interface, and subscribe to the Bulk folder in TB if the account is set up as IMAP.
creator: sfhowes

content: I am talking about the Bulk mail folder in ThunderBird itself. The emails are delivered to TB and for some reason go the the TB bulk mail folder and I never see them.
creator: ClayL

content:
TB creates a Junk folder, if Junk Controls are enabled. Bulk is a folder created by the mail service, and it can be subscribed in TB if the account is IMAP. Anything that goes to Bulk does so before Bulk is downloaded to TB.

If you want to see notifications for Bulk, right-click Bulk, Properties, check 'when getting new messages...'.

content:
Generally this occurs with folk using IMAP mail with Hotmail/outlook domains and Google.

What occurs is both of those providers and Thunderbird make a copy of the email to go in the sent folder, resulting in two copies being saved.

As neither provider gives you the option of disabling their helpful copy, the only alternative is to disable that in Thunderbird. Account settings > copies and folders and change it to not save a copy.

The draw back is Google at least do not save the BCC information on sent mail, retaining only "undisclosed recipients" so if retaining this informai0on is at all important, you probably should allow Thunderbird to continue making a copy and perhaps save in in the local folder > sent folder to reduce confusion.
creator: MattAuSupport

content:
Firewall - Thunderbird must be set up as an allowed program. Otherwise ports may get blocked. So exit Thunderbird, access Firewall and check all is set up ok.

These are the server settings you should be using: Do as follows to check:

  • Menu icon > Account Settings
  • In LEFT PANE scroll to bottom and below 'Local Folders' account click on 'Outgoing Server SMTP'

It will show a list of all your outgoing servers. You should have one for each email address/mail account

  • Select each in turn until you find the one which has the 'User name' for problem account.
  • Click on 'Edit'

SMTP settings:

  • Description: enter full email address - same as the user name
  • Server name: mail.ykwc.com
  • Outgoing Port: 587
  • Connection Security : STARTTLS (one webage says SSL, but state to use STARTTLS in a help pdf)

It is usual to use STARTTLS with port 587.

  • Authentication Method: Normal Password
  • User name: full email address

If you do not have an smtp server set up for the email address then click on 'Add' and create one.

Then make sure the account is actually using the correct SMTP server. In LEFT PANE

  • select the name of the problem mail account
  • Look bottom right for 'Outgoing Server SMTP'
  • It should be displaying the email address because you put it in the description field.
  • If it is not showing the email address of the account then click on the drop down option and choose the correct smtp settings.
  • DO NOT click on 'Edit SMTP_Server' button because you may end up editing the wrong one.

Now Check your password

  • Menu icon > Settings > Privacy & Security
  • Under 'Passwords' section
  • Click on 'Saved passwords'
  • click on 'Show Passwords'

IF the smtp://account is not listed then it should get saved after a restart and prompt for password.

If smtp://account line is shown but you want to force all the updated settings, then select the smt://account line for that email address and click on 'Remove'.

If all the SMTP settings were completely correct and you did not have to edit or add anything, then reenter the password.

  • Right click on the correct 'smtp:// account line where 'User Name' = problem email address and select 'Edit Password'
  • Completely remove contents and type in the correct password
  • Click on 'Close'


Exit Thunderbird and wait a few moments for background processes to complete then restart Thunderbird.

Suggest you wait for an incoming email to that same account before attempting to send. When sending - If prompted for password:

  • Enter Password and select checkbox to Remember Password before you click on OK

content:
re :I have a problem with Thunderbird (migrated to POP3)

When you say 'migrated' to pop3, can you clarify what you mean. I just need to be reassured that you have not mangled up an imap account to use pop account server settings.

Which of the following describes what you mean by 'migrated to pop3':

  1. Did you originally have an imap mail account for that email address, but then access the Account Settings and edited the server settings to use pop server settings?
  2. Did you originally have an imap mail account for that email address, but chose to completely remove that imap account. Then created a 'New' > 'Existing Mail Account' for that same email address, but this time you used the 'Configure Manually' option to set up a POP mail account and use the pop server settings ?
  3. Did you never have an imap account for that email address; you originally created a 'New' > 'Existing Mail Account' for that email address, using the 'Configure Manually' option to set up as POP and use the pop server settings ?
creator: Toad-Hall
